articles.headline: Reverse Mortgages Here to Stay
articles.snippet: Reverse mortgages may not be the best income-producing products for retirees, but they may become necessary last resorts.
articles.abstract: Reverse mortgages may not be the best income-producing products for retirees, but they may become necessary last resorts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Reverse mortgages will help millions of people stay in their homes and pay for a variety of retirement expenses in the coming decades.

articles.headline: Bribery, but Nobody Was Charged
articles.snippet: In his debut column for The Times, James B. Stewart writes about the Tyson Foods bribery case, in which no one at the company was charged despite its admission to making illegal payments to veterinarians in Mexico.
articles.abstract: In his debut column for The Times, James B. Stewart writes about the Tyson Foods bribery case, in which no one at the company was charged despite its admission to making illegal payments to veterinarians in Mexico.
articles.lead_paragraph: In late June 2004, a plant manager for one of Tyson Foods’ poultry processing plants in Mexico sent a memo to company headquarters in Springdale, Ark.: two women who “most definitely do not work for Tyson Foods in Mexico” each were paid 30,700 pesos, or about $2,700, a month and had been for years. Tyson is one of the world’s largest producers of poultry, pork and beef products, a ubiquitous presence in American supermarkets that has been trying to increase foreign sales. The memo set off an ethics scandal that reached into Tyson’s executive suite and raises questions about who, if anyone, is being held accountable for high-level corporate crime.

articles.headline: House Spurns Obama on Libya, but Does Not Cut Funds
articles.snippet: The House dealt a symbolic blow to President Obama by rejecting a bill to authorize the operations in Libya, but also turned back a measure that would have cut financing for the effort.
articles.abstract: The House dealt a symbolic blow to President Obama by rejecting a bill to authorize the operations in Libya, but also turned back a measure that would have cut financing for the effort.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House dealt a symbolic blow to President Obama on Friday by resoundingly rejecting a bill to authorize United States military operations in Libya. But the chamber also defeated a measure that would have limited financing to support those efforts.

articles.headline: F.D.A. Urges Less Use of Anemia Drugs
articles.snippet: Regulators said that there were no risk-free doses of Epogen, Aranesp and Procrit and that doctors should use the medicines only in patients suffering from severe anemia.
articles.abstract: Regulators said that there were no risk-free doses of Epogen, Aranesp and Procrit and that doctors should use the medicines only in patients suffering from severe anemia.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal drug regulators said on Friday that three drugs that had been widely used to treat anemia in both kidney and cancer patients were so dangerous to the heart that doctors should consider avoiding the medicines altogether in some patients and using less of them in others.

articles.headline: Charity Goes Mobile to Appeal to Young
articles.snippet: Do Something, a nonprofit group that urges teenagers to do civic activities, is using mobile technology in an effort to sign up 3.8 million members by 2014.
articles.abstract: Do Something, a nonprofit group that urges teenagers to do civic activities, is using mobile technology in an effort to sign up 3.8 million members by 2014.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nancy Lublin was sitting in her office in Manhattan one evening last December when she noticed her staff outside giving one another high fives, pumping their fists and generally engaged in raucous celebration.

articles.headline: ‘Safety Myth’ Left Japan Ripe for Nuclear Crisis
articles.snippet: Japan’s nuclear establishment has devoted vast resources to convince the public of the safety and necessity of nuclear power.
articles.abstract: Japan’s nuclear establishment has devoted vast resources to convince the public of the safety and necessity of nuclear power.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHIKA, Japan — Near a nuclear power plant facing the Sea of Japan, a series of exhibitions in a large public relations building here extols the virtues of the energy source with some help from “Alice in Wonderland.”

articles.headline: 2 by 2, or Not, Zoo Animals Escape Flood
articles.snippet: As the floodwaters climbed to levels never before recorded in Minot, N.D., workers at the local zoo endeavored to evacuate the animals in the least chaotic way possible.
articles.abstract: As the floodwaters climbed to levels never before recorded in Minot, N.D., workers at the local zoo endeavored to evacuate the animals in the least chaotic way possible.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINOT, N.D. — As a historic flood threatened to drown this city, the animals from the local zoo were evacuated to a warehouse high above the valley floor. There were two of every sort — donkeys, hedgehogs, bald eagles, reindeer, toucans and many others — packed together in a makeshift sanctuary.

articles.headline: Denmark Leads Nationalist Challenge to Europe’s Open Borders
articles.snippet: Denmark is part of a trend in which far-right parties are mounting an assault on the European Union’s main institutions: the euro zone and free trade across open borders.
articles.abstract: Denmark is part of a trend in which far-right parties are mounting an assault on the European Union’s main institutions: the euro zone and free trade across open borders.
articles.lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN — Ten years ago, as Denmark joined the European Union’s visa-free open travel zone, the outraged Danish People’s Party bought a decommissioned border guardhouse, vowing that one day it would be in use again.

articles.headline: Findings That May Get Lost
articles.snippet: Regulatory findings in a case involving Morgan Keegan, the brokerage firm in Memphis, might not be allowed as evidence in some arbitration proceedings.
articles.abstract: Regulatory findings in a case involving Morgan Keegan, the brokerage firm in Memphis, might not be allowed as evidence in some arbitration proceedings.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEWS arrived last week that Morgan Keegan, a big name in what might be called Wall Street South, apparently duped investors in some of its mutual funds.

articles.headline: Job Jugglers, on the Tightrope
articles.snippet: Out of necessity or choice, many people are weaving together a smattering of part-time positions to pay the bills.
articles.abstract: Out of necessity or choice, many people are weaving together a smattering of part-time positions to pay the bills.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN someone asks Roger Fierro “What do you do?” — which he knows is shorthand for “Where do you work?” — he laughs. Then he says, “I do everything.”

articles.headline: In Medicine, New Isn’t Always Improved
articles.snippet: Metal hip implants are one example of unexpected problems coming from seeming medical breakthroughs.
articles.abstract: Metal hip implants are one example of unexpected problems coming from seeming medical breakthroughs.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT is an American impulse to covet the new and improved — whether it’s a faster computer, a smarter cellphone or a more fuel-efficient car. And in medicine, too, new drugs, devices and procedures have advanced patient care.

articles.headline: Building Boom in Gaza’s Ruins Belies Misery That Remains
articles.snippet: Houses are going up and new cars are on the road, but destroyed homes have not been rebuilt, and people remain impoverished and trapped.
articles.abstract: Houses are going up and new cars are on the road, but destroyed homes have not been rebuilt, and people remain impoverished and trapped.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA — Two luxury hotels are opening in Gaza this month. Thousands of new cars are plying the roads. A second shopping mall — with escalators imported from Israel — will open next month. Hundreds of homes and two dozen schools are about to go up. A Hamas-run farm where Jewish settlements once stood is producing enough fruit that Israeli imports are tapering off.

articles.headline: Insiders Sound an Alarm Amid a Natural Gas Rush
articles.snippet: As investment floods into shale wells, concerns about their productivity are spurring talk of a bubble.
articles.abstract: As investment floods into shale wells, concerns about their productivity are spurring talk of a bubble.
articles.lead_paragraph: Natural gas companies have been placing enormous bets on the wells they are drilling, saying they will deliver big profits and provide a vast new source of energy for the United States.

articles.headline: Bridge Comes to San Francisco With a Made-in-China Label
articles.snippet: China, in its continual move up the global economic value chain — from cheap toys to jetliners — now aims to be the world’s civil engineer.
articles.abstract: China, in its continual move up the global economic value chain — from cheap toys to jetliners — now aims to be the world’s civil engineer.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Talk about outsourcing.

articles.headline: Chaos in Yemen Creates Opening for Islamist Gangs
articles.snippet: The port city of Aden is now surrounded by roving gangs who have captured at least two towns, stormed prisons and looted banks and military depots.
articles.abstract: The port city of Aden is now surrounded by roving gangs who have captured at least two towns, stormed prisons and looted banks and military depots.
articles.lead_paragraph: ADEN, Yemen — The ancient port city of Aden is now virtually surrounded by roving gangs of Islamist militia fighters — some linked to Al Qaeda — who have captured at least two towns, stormed prisons and looted banks and military depots in southern Yemen.

articles.headline: For the Producer of ‘Survivor’ and ‘The Voice,’ There’s No Sitting Still
articles.snippet: For Mark Burnett, the reality television producer who has five prime-time series on the air in America, being busy is one of the keys to his success.
articles.abstract: For Mark Burnett, the reality television producer who has five prime-time series on the air in America, being busy is one of the keys to his success.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mark Burnett, who more or less created the reality programming business in American television, is back in the ratings fast lane.

articles.headline: A Newsroom That Doesn’t Need News
articles.snippet: Online and on TV, TMZ has earned a huge following by airing Hollywood’s dirty laundry.
articles.abstract: Online and on TV, TMZ has earned a huge following by airing Hollywood’s dirty laundry.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES It is 6:30 in the morning, and a stubborn mist is hanging low over the Hollywood Hills.

articles.headline: The Right’s Blogger Provocateur
articles.snippet: Andrew Breitbart uses his network of Web sites and their legions of followers to bring conservative media red meat.
articles.abstract: Andrew Breitbart uses his network of Web sites and their legions of followers to bring conservative media red meat.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Andrew Breitbart wasn’t supposed to be sitting here in a television studio makeup chair. But when he heard that Anthony Weiner was about to announce his resignation, he dropped everything.

articles.headline: Dissolution of Hacker Group Might Not End Attacks
articles.snippet: In its farewell, Lulz Security urged other hackers to join the “revolution” aimed at governments and corporations.
articles.abstract: In its farewell, Lulz Security urged other hackers to join the “revolution” aimed at governments and corporations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facing increasing pressure from law enforcement agencies over its brazen computer attacks, the small group of hackers known as Lulz Security announced over the weekend that it would disband.
articles.byline: By Riva Richmond and Nick Bilton

articles.headline: Genentech to Appeal to F.D.A. for Breast Cancer Drug
articles.snippet: Genentech will ask the F.D.A. to rethink its proposal to revoke the approval of Avastin for breast cancer on the grounds that new studies did not confirm that the drug helped patients.
articles.abstract: Genentech will ask the F.D.A. to rethink its proposal to revoke the approval of Avastin for breast cancer on the grounds that new studies did not confirm that the drug helped patients.
articles.lead_paragraph: Genentech this week will step up its efforts to keep the drug Avastin available as a treatment for breast cancer, urging the Food and Drug Administration to give it one more chance to prove the medicine works.

articles.headline: Behind Veneer, Doubt on Future of Natural Gas
articles.snippet: Energy companies have worked hard to promote natural gas as the fossil fuel of tomorrow, and they have found reliable allies in Washington. But not everyone agrees.
articles.abstract: Energy companies have worked hard to promote natural gas as the fossil fuel of tomorrow, and they have found reliable allies in Washington. But not everyone agrees.
articles.lead_paragraph: Energy companies have worked hard to promote the idea that natural gas is the fossil fuel of tomorrow, and they have found reliable allies among policy makers in Washington.

articles.headline: Auditor Warns of Risks From Local Debt in China
articles.snippet: Local government debt reached $1.6 trillion, or 27 percent of gross domestic product, last year, the auditor said.
articles.abstract: Local government debt reached $1.6 trillion, or 27 percent of gross domestic product, last year, the auditor said.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — The head of China’s national audit office warned on Monday that the country was facing growing risks because of a sharp rise in local government debt and poor controls over borrowing by investment companies set up by municipalities, provinces and other bodies.

articles.headline: Justices Reject Ban on Violent Video Games for Children
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court agreed with a federal court’s decision to throw out California’s ban on the sale or rental of violent video games to minors, saying the law violated minors’ rights.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court agreed with a federal court’s decision to throw out California’s ban on the sale or rental of violent video games to minors, saying the law violated minors’ rights.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday struck down on First Amendment grounds a California law that banned the sale of violent video games to children. The 7-to-2 decision was the latest in a series of rulings protecting free speech, joining ones on funeral protests, videos showing cruelty to animals and political speech by corporations.
